text:

A vote to leave the EU could tear apart the United Kingdom – the Bishop of Durham has warned. 
Voters will go to the polls on June 23 for the once in a generation chance to vote on the UK’s future in the European Union and as the debate on whether to stay or go heats up the Bishop has spoken out. 
The Right Reverend Paul Butler declared his support for the Remain campaign on Friday, speaking at Auckland Castle, the historic seat of the Bishop of Durham . 
Rt Rev Butler argued the country will need to do a great deal of “healing” after the referendum , no matter what the outcome of the vote. 
He said: “What happens if Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales vote to stay and England votes to leave? What if London votes to stay and other regions vote to leave? 
“The vote to leave raises serious concerns about the unity of the nation.” 
The Rt. Revd Paul Butler, Bishop of Durham

The North East’s most senior religious figure added his support to the remain campaign after months of thinking and praying, he said. 
Rt Rev Butler said that he believes a vote to remain in the EU is the best thing for the UK as a whole. 
He said: “At our best Britain is a generous, welcoming, hospitable nation that has a wider role in the world. Being art of the EU is the best way to support and express that.” 
The Bishop, who sits in the House of Lords said his decision to come out and support one side of the referendum was partly driven by his disappointment at the rhetoric of the campaigns so far. 
He said: “I have been very deeply concerned that this while debate has been reduced to being about economic and migration. 
“It is about peace, the well-being of ordinary people, how we engage with the world. It is much bigger than simply economics or migration. 
“I think a lot of the tone has been very unfortunate, it’s become too personalised in some instances. It’s become too focused on economics and migration when for me it’s about peace and wellbeing of nations together.” 
The Bishop refrained from giving voters direction how to vote and said: “People must make up their own minds and then go out and vote on the day.” 
Earlier this week he signed a letter along with over 150 senior business leaders, who say the region could face financial difficulties if the nation voted to leave the EU. 
He added: “For the North East, being part of the EU has been really important for manufacturing, for farming. We as a region feel the benefits of being in the EU. 
“I believe it is the best thing for the North East, and the nation as a whole.” The European Union debate
